clinicalDescription: Overview: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell. Causes cancer cells to accumulate in the bone marrow, where they crowd out healthy blood cells and produce abnormal proteins. Three stages are I - III. There are alos other plasma cell disorders (Monoclonal gammopathy of uncertain significance (MGUS), smoldering multiple myeloma, Solitary plasmacytoma, and light chain amyloidosis)Presentation: Can have no symptoms (smoldering multiple myeloma). Bone pain, nausea, constipation, loss of appetite, confusion, fatigue, frequent infections, weight loss, weakness, and excessive thirst Assessment: Thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia and anemia. Blood tests may reveal M proteins and beta-2-microglobulin (produced by myeloma cells), urine tests (Bence Jones proteins), bone marrow aspiration and biopsy (FISH - fluorescence in situ hybridization), imaging tests Plan: Stabilize and slow the progress of multiple myeloma. If no signs, no treatement. If signs and progression - targeted therapy, biological, chemotherapy, radiation, corticosteroids, bone marrow transplant Prognosis: No cure, but can be managed successfully in many patients for years
